metadata.case_name: Assessee (Registered Firm owning Nedous Hotel) v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Assessee is a registered firm deriving income from interest on securities, property, business and other sources.
In 1946, assessee purchased Nedous Hotel in Lahore for Rs. 46 lakhs, raising loan of Rs. 30 lakhs from Bharat Bank Ltd., Lahore and Rs. 18 lakhs from Raja of Jubbal.
Assessee agreed with Raja of Jubbal: Raja accepted half share in property in lieu of loan and 1/3rd of outstanding bank liability, effective November 1, 1951.
After creation of Pakistan, property declared evacuee property and vested in Custodian in Pakistan.
Relevant assessment years: 1952-53, 1955-56, 1956-57; accounting periods ending March 31, 1952, March 31, 1955, March 31, 1956.
In returns, assessee claimed losses: Rs. 1,00,723 (1952-53), Rs. 1,16,599 (1955-56), Rs. 1,16,599 (1956-57) on account of interest payable to bank; gross annual letting value shown as Nil.
Income-tax Officer disallowed claim as property vested in Custodian, no income or loss to be considered.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO's order.
Tribunal held assessee continued as owner for computation of loss; interest deductible under s. 9(1)(iv); relied on its decision for 1951-52.
Delhi High Court (Full Bench, S.K. Kapur J.) on Sept 20, 1967 held assessee not owner under s.9 of Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances, the assessee continued to be the owner of the property for purposes of computation of income under s. 9 of Income-tax Act, 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred; property vested in Custodian only for administration; assessee continued as owner.
Owner means person having ultimate right to property.
So long as assessee had right to property, even if hedged or restricted, continued as owner.
Evacuee has residual ownership; relied on Amar Singh v. Custodian.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Amar Singh v. Custodian, Evacuee Property, Punjab

respondent_arguments.text: Income-tax concerned with income, gains, profits; owner is person entitled to income.
Word 'owner' in s.9 refers to legal ownership, not beneficial interest.

court_reasoning.text: Analyzed Pakistan Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949: property vested in Custodian from March 1, 1947 (s.6); Custodian has powers to possess, manage, sell, etc. (ss.9,11,12,14,16,19,20); evacuee cannot deal without consent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Custodian exercises all owner rights; evacuee has only beneficial interest; Custodian is legal owner.

court_reasoning.text: s.9 taxes income from property of which assessee is owner; owner is person who can exercise rights in own right, entitled to income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Focus on receipt of income; property cannot be owned by two with exclusive rights.

court_reasoning.text: Practical view: Evacuees would pay tax on unrealized income if considered owners.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interpret reasonably in consonance with justice.

court_reasoning.text: Followed Official Assignee case: Assignee vested with property is owner u/s.9; similar to Custodian.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No difference between legal and equitable estate here.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Amar Singh: Residual right not ownership u/s.9.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word 'owner' context-specific; s.9 focuses on income receipt.

holdings.text: Assessee was not the owner of Nedous Hotel during relevant assessment years for purpose of s.9 of Income-tax Act, 1922.

precedents_cited.case_name: Official Assignee for Bengal Estate of Jnanendra Nath Pramanik
precedents_cited.relevance: Official Assignee vested with property is owner u/s.9; powers similar to Custodian.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Fleming
precedents_cited.relevance: Income from sequestrated estate is trustee's, not insolvent's; test is entitlement to income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Trustees of Sir Currimbhoy Ebrahim Baronetcy Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports no difference between legal and equitable estate in this context.

precedents_cited.case_name: Amar Singh v. Custodian, Evacuee Property, Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Evacuee has residual ownership under Art.19(1)(f), but not for s.9.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja P. Lal Choudhary v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Receiver not owner as property does not vest; distinguishes from trustee/assignee.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nawab Bahadur of Murshidabad v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Owner u/s.9 liable even with alienation restrictions if entitled to whole income.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Determines tax on bona fide annual value of property of which assessee is owner; interest deductible if owner.

statutes_cited.name: Pakistan Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 (XV of 1949)
statutes_cited.relevance: Vests evacuee property in Custodian for administration; confers all owner powers on Custodian.

statutes_cited.name: Presidency Towns Insolvency Act, 1909
statutes_cited.relevance: Property vests in Official Assignee, who is owner u/s.9 analogous to Custodian.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held assessee not owner of property under s.9 of Income-tax Act, 1922 as it vested in Custodian under Pakistan Ordinance; appeals dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "The property having vested in the Custodian, who had all the powers of the owner, he was the legal owner of the property. In the eye of the law, the Custodian was the owner of that property."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "For the purpose of s.9, the owner must be that person who can exercise the rights of the owner, not on behalf of the owner but in his own right."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key test for ownership in taxation of property income.

key_quotes.text: "s.9 brings to tax the income from property and not the interest of a person in the property."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies focus of s.9 on income receipt.
